feed.title: Current Watches, Warnings and Advisories for the United States Issued by the National Weather Service

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 03 at 4:41PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Late Tonight Through Monday Night... Snow is expected above 3000 feet from late tonight through Monday night. Several inches is possible above 3000 feet, with up to 4 inches above 4000 feet. Snow will taper off Monday night.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 03 at 4:39PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Snow Above 4000 Feet through Monday... Snow is expected above 4000 feet from late tonight through Monday night. Up to 3 inches above 4000 feet. Snow will taper off Monday night.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 03 at 4:39PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...High Water on the Tanana River and Tributaries Draining the Alaska Range Continues This Week... High water on the Tanana River and tributaries draining the Alaska Range will continue this week. This includes the Chisana River, Nabesna River, Gerstle River, Delta River, and the Nenana River. entry.cap:areaDesc: Deltana and Tanana Flats; Upper Tanana Valley and the Fortymile Country

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 03 at 1:16PM AKDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...HIGH WATER EXPECTED TO CONTINUE IN THE SUSITNA BASIN... High water levels can be expected to continue on the Susitna River and its tributaries through the next couple of days. This includes the Talkeetna, Yentna, Skwentna, Kashwitna and Little Susitna Rivers and associated streams such as Willow, Montana and Moose Creeks.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued September 03 at 3:08PM CDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...ELEVATED FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS MONDAY... A combination of the ongoing drought, record to near-record hot temperatures, relative humidity values near 30% and southerly winds sustained at 10 to 15 mph, with gusts to 20 mph will bring elevated fire weather conditions to portions of central, northern and eastern Wisconsin Monday.

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued September 03 at 2:14PM MDT by NWS
entry.summary: ...Pacific System Brings Chance for Heavy Rain and Localized Flooding... A Pacific System brings above normal moisture values to Wyoming through Tuesday morning. Locations west of the Continental Divide, mainly over the higher terrain, are expected to get the highest rainfall totals through this period, with 1 to 2 inches expected.
